case_name: East India Industries Limited v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1399 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1399 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 62 of 1958 (Reference No. 37 of 1958).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 62 of 1958  Reference No. 37 of 1958 . Swaminathan and R. Gopalkrishnan, for the

facts.text: The assessee is East India Industries Limited.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, the East India Industries Limited, paid a donation of Rs. 7,500 to a trust called the Agastyar Trust and claimed exemption from tax under S. 14-B

facts.text: Assessee paid a donation of Rs. 7,500 to Agastyar Trust.

anchor.surface_text: paid a donation of Rs. 7,500 to a trust called the Agastyar Trust and claimed exemption from tax under S. 14-B of the Income- tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Assessee claimed exemption from tax under S. 15-B of the Income-tax Act, 1922 for the donation.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed exemption from tax under S. 14-B of the Income- tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act. The trust had been created by the partners of a business firm, K. Rajagopal and Company.

facts.text: Agastyar Trust created by partners of business firm K. Rajagopal and Company.

anchor.surface_text: The trust had been created by the partners of a business firm, K. Rajagopal and Company. This firm had been carrying on business in Waste paper.

facts.text: K. Rajagopal and Company carried on business in Waste paper.

anchor.surface_text: This firm had been carrying on business in Waste paper. Under the terms of the partnership it was setting apart 80 per cent of the profits for charitable and religious purposes.

facts.text: Partnership terms set apart 80 per cent of profits for charitable and religious purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the partnership it was setting apart 80 per cent of the profits for charitable and religious purposes. On July 1, 1944, a trust deed was executed by Venkatarama Chetti.

facts.text: Trust deed for Agastyar Trust executed on July 1, 1944 by Venkatarama Chetti.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1944, a trust deed was executed by Venkatarama Chetti. The claim of the assessee to exemption from tax was rejected by the Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Income Tax Officer rejected assessee's claim to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the assessee to exemption from tax was rejected by the Income Tax Officer on the ground that the trust did number fulfil the companyditions laid down under S. 15-B of the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner to whom an appeal was preferred took the same view. The matter was taken up in further appeal to the Incometax Appellate Tribunal

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held in previous assessment year that Agastyar Trust was public trust and donation allowable under s. 15-B.

anchor.surface_text: which observed that in relation to the previous assessment year, it had held that the Agastyar Trust was a public trust and that any donation made to that trust was an allowable deduction under s. 15-B.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question of law to High Court at instance of Commissioner of Income-tax under s. 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissionerof Income-tax the Tribunal referred the following question of law for the determination of the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: Question referred: Whether on the facts and circumstances the assessee is entitled to claim deduction under Section 15-B in respect of the donation to Agastyar Trust.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the cirmustances of the case the assessee is entitled to claim deduction under Section 15-B in respect of the donation paid to the Agastyar Trust ?

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the assesee who has brought the present appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal brought by special leave.

holdings.text: one of the objects of the trust, namely item 4, is not for charitable or religious purposes.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it appears from the deed of trust that one of the objects of the trust, namely item 4, is number for charitable or religious purposes. Item No. 4 is to manufacture, buy, sell and distribute pharmaceutical, medicinal, chemical, and other preparations and articles such as medicines, drugs, medical and surgical articles, preparations and restoratives of food.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of clause 2(d) of trust deed shows object of manufacturing/selling pharmaceuticals is neither charitable nor religious.

holdings.text: under cl. 5(i) of the trust deed it is open to the trustees to utilise the income for any one of the objects of the trust to the exclusion of all other objects... it would not be a violation of the trust if the trustees devoted the entire income to the carrying on of a business of manufacture, sale and distribution of pharmaceutical, medicinal and other preparations.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is numberspecial trust, that is to say, numberparticular item of property has been burdened with the performance of any specific object of the trust. It is therefore manifest that under cl. 5 i  of the trust deed it is open to the trustees to utilise the income for any one of the objects of the trust to the exclusion of all other objects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No special trust created; clause 5(i) permits trustees to apply entire income to single object, including non-charitable item 4.

holdings.text: We are unable to hold that there is any connection between the two objects of the trust and upon an interpretation of the document taken as a whole, it is impossible to accept the appellants contention that cl. 2(c) is the dominant object of the trust and cl. 2(d) is a subsidiary object.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that there is any companynection between the two objects of the trust and upon an interpretation of the document taken as a whole, it is impossible to accept the appellants companytention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects harmonious construction linking 2(d) to preceding 2(c) (hospitals); clauses independent per trust deed.

holdings.text: the trust deed, on a proper interpretation, gives an absolute power of selection to the trustees to choose between charitable and non-charitable objects of the trust for spending the entire income of the trust properties.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the language of paragraph 2 of the trust deed in the companytext of other paragraphs of the document, we are of opinion that the trust deed, on a proper interpretation, gives an absolute power

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall document interpretation, esp. para 2 last clause, confers trustee discretion over independent objects.

holdings.text: the Agastyar trust does not fulfil the conditions imposed by s. 4(3)(i) of the Act and the donation made by the assessee to the Agastyar trust cannot therefore be exempted under s. 15-B of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-charitable object + trustee discretion fails 'wholly' requirement of s.4(3)(i), prerequisite for s.15-B exemption.

holdings.text: if there are several objects of the trust, some of which are charitable and some non-charitable, and the trustees have unfettered discretion to apply the income to any of the objects, the whole trust would fail and no part of the income would be exempt from tax.

anchor.surface_text: The view that we have expressed is borne out by the decision of the Judicial Committee in Mohammad Ibrahim Riza v. Commissioner of Income-,tax, Nagpur 1  in which it was held that if there  1 57 I.A. 260. are several objects...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies JC precedent in Mohammad Ibrahim Riza to facts: mixed objects + discretion voids exemption.

holdings.text: the High Court rightly answered the question of law against the assessee and in favour of the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: We  1  17 T. C. 27, 40. accordingly hold that the High Court rightly answered the question of law against the assessee and in favour of the Commissioner of Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court on s.15-B denial based on s.4(3)(i) failure.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Ibrahim Riza v. Commissioner of Income Tax Nagpur
precedents.cited_proposition: if there are several objects of the trust, some of which are charitable and some non-charitable, and the trustees have unfettered discretion to apply the income to any of the objects, the whole trust would fail and no part of the income would be exempt from tax

precedents.case_name: Oxford Group v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: maintenance, support, development and assistance of the Oxford Group Movement in every way extended beyond purely religious activities and permitted engagement in non-charitable activities, so the company could not be said to be established for charitable purposes only

precedents.case_name: Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: it is not enough that the purposes described in the memorandum should include charitable purposes, the memorandum must be confined to those purposes so that any application of funds to non-charitable purposes would be ultra vires
precedents.cited_holding: The instrument ... must be confined to those purposes so that any application by the company of its funds to non-charitable purposes would be ultra vires
